title: council-debate-making-20mph-limits-permanent
story: PLANS to make the mph limits in the Borders permanent will go before Scottish Borders Councilnext week.The reduced speed limits across  towns and villages in the region were introduced in October  as part of the Spaces For People programme.A report which includes data collected by Edinburgh Napier University during the trial showing a reduction in vehicle speeds in areas where the new limit was introduced, will be discussed by councillors at a full council meeting on Thursday, December .Councillor Gordon Edgar, executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport, said: ldquoThe introduction of a mph speed limit across our towns and villages was a bold step but we felt it was important to give it a try and see what benefits it would bring.ldquoBy working with Edinburgh Napier Universityrsquos Transport Research Institute on this project, we were able to get a completely independent evaluation of the trialrsquos effectiveness. The fact their data shows a reduction in speeds across the Borders is really encouraging news."A public consultation was also conducted, and feedback on the mph speed limits was also sought from local community councils.Using the data and feedback from the public, the report recommends that the mph limit be the "default" around towns and villages, with some areas retaining "mph or mph buffer zones in place where suitable".The buffer zones will be away from residential areas and on stretches of road "where it is felt driving at mph is dficult to justy and particularly challenging".Mr Edgar added: ldquoI would like to thank everyone that contributed to the public consultation, providing really valuable local insight and opinions. The responses were ied but it was clear that many people noted the value of a mph limit especially in residential areas and near schools.ldquoCouncillors will now discuss and vote on this proposal on Thursday and I hope they can support the permanent introduction of mph, making our towns and villages safer for all for years to come.

title: new-borders-coronavirus-cases-recorded-24-hour-period
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirus in a -hour period, latest figures show.An update was published by the Scottish Government at pm today .And the new data shows that the Borders has now seen , coronavirus cases since the start of the pandemic.There are nine people in hospital in the Borders with recently confirmed cases of COVID-.Scotland has now recorded , cases since March last year.

title: old-craighall-slip-road-closed-overnight-friday-10-december
story: THE slip road from the A Edinburgh City Bypass onto the northbound A at Old Craighall Junction will be closed for carriageway repairs tonight Friday  December.This closure will be in place from : on Friday  December until : on Saturday  December.A ersion for traffic wishing to join the A northbound at Old Craighall will be signposted via the A southbound, ing northbound from Wallyford Junction.Emergency services and other relevant stakeholders have been consulted in advance to make them aware of the plans.Tommy Deans, BEAR Scotlandrsquos South East Network Manager, said: ldquoIt is essential that we close the slip road during these works to ensure the safety of road workers and motorists, however wersquove arranged for the work to take place overnight to minimise the impact.ldquoWe thank motorists and the local community in advance for their patience and understanding.

title: festive-family-fun-earlston-lights-switch
story: THE cold didnrsquot deter crowds from gathering in Earlston at the weekend to celebrate the festive season at the townrsquos annual Christmas lights switch on.Thanks to the efforts of Earlston Community Council, the Christmas Lights Committee, Earlston In Bloom and a whole host of volunteers, the switch-on event was a success.Volunteers from Earlston In Bloom worked on Saturday to create their festive foliage displays which decorated lampposts around the town.A community council spokesperson said: ldquoCongratulations to all the local volunteers who make this display come to le each year and great to see another good turn out for the  Switch On.ldquoThank goodness it wasnrsquot planned for Saturday ndash despite the weather Earlston in Bloomrsquos volunteers got all  bunches of festive foliage up safely.On Sunday evening locals and visitors were treated to music performed by Jedforest Instrumental Band.And arriving on a tinsel-covered tricycle, Father Christmas took selfies with youngsters and turned on the Christmas lights.Members of the public shared their praise of the switch on event on social media,with Carol Rae sharing: ldquoWell done the Christmas lights crew ..st class job again, and Shirley Smith said: ldquoGreat show, well done to all.

title: parking-issues-raised-innerleithen-resident
story: A PEEBLESSHIRE resident has raised concerns about mountain bikers parking their cars in "really hazardous" areas near his home.In a letter sent to Innerleithen Community Council chairman Marshall Douglas, John Paterson, of The Ley, said that during the weekends and summer months the layby adjacent to his driveway and the green spaces along the B are ldquorammed with vehicles which have flocked to the region.At a meeting of the community council on Monday , Mr Paterson shared his concerns and requested that action be taken to tackle the issue, described by one councillor as ldquohellish.ldquoWersquove always had issues with camping, wersquove even had some trees chopped down by people camping there, litter, people urinating and defecating either on my property or at my entrance which is pretty unpleasant as you can imagine," he said. ldquoAnd it just seems to have reached a real pitch in recent times.ldquoI know itrsquos been very bad for some while now at the likes of the Cauld and the golf club used to have a lot of problems with people parking there as well.Mr Paterson has spoken with Police Scotland about the issue and it was suggested to put up bollards or reflector posts around the bend to discourage people from parking on the verges.Tweeddale East councillor Robin Tatlersaid he would look into solutions.He said: ldquoI absolutely sympathise with you. I can understand that this must be absolutely hellish.ldquoIn the short term we need to do something immediately about trying to discourage people from parking in inappropriate places and Irsquom more than happy to take that forward to the community action teamwith the police.ldquoI think in the medium term we need to be trying to encourage people, when there are peak times, to not park there but to park down in the town.Also at this weekrsquos meeting was Emma Guy from Enduro World Series , who formerly worked as project coordinator for the Tweed Valley Tourism Bid..removeShe said: ldquoIrsquom well aware of this issue and some of us [from Tweed Valley Tourism Bid] did try and tackle it on the ground about a year and a half ago with putting signs up near the Cauld.ldquoSo around the event at the beginning of October we had shuttles so people wouldnrsquot park in these hotspots, we cordoned off areas, we spoke to the golf club and we had marshals in place to police any bad behaviour, so tat worked quite well.ldquoOur kind of feeling is that this is an ongoing problem and it does need solutions, there needs to be some kind of visitor infrastructure investment and certainly in my role with the Tourism Bid we were pushing really hard for that.ldquoFrom an EWS point of view, with regard to events, we worked quite hard to manage that problem because we know how disruptive and how unpleasant that can be.ldquoIn my role with EWS we would support and put our weight behind any proposals to the council to SOSEto try and alleviate this.Tweeddale East councillor Shona Haslam, of the Conservatives, added: ldquoIn terms of the long term [solution] obviously wersquove got pound million coming into mountain biking infrastructure into Innerleithen and pound million for a town the size of Innerleithen is pretty signicant.ldquoSo, wersquove got the Mountain Biking Innovation Centre that is moving forward in the background, obviously therersquos a lot of commercial stuff in there that wersquore not allowed to talk about, and there is the bike park as well. There is going to be signicant parking and infrastructure and resources.

title: peebles-pupils-recognised-prize-giving-ceremony
story: PEEBLES High recently celebrated its annual prize-giving event. Here, members of the schoolrsquos higher journalism class interview some of the winners and those involved on the day...Headteacherrsquos messageThis year we celebrate our amazing young people and their astounding achievements in their studies through the medium of the printed press. Is it the same as enjoying the embarrassment of your granny cheering from the front row  Or as rewarding as seeing the pride on the faces of family members as you collect your certicate on stage with a smile and a handshake  Of course not. Nothing about school le post-fire post during COVID seems as rewarding or real as it once did but, be in no doubt, the young people celebrated here today are every bit as worthy of celebration and congratulations as their predecessors and perhaps even more so given all they have had to overcome and deal with to win the prizes we celebrate in this article.Perhaps you can take heart that this yearrsquos Peebles High School prize giving offers something more permanent than fleeting moments of adulation and applause. It offers an article than can be cherished for years to come as a reminder of how our young people triumphed against the odds. Who knows, perhaps in years to come one of this yearrsquos prize winners will be a granny or grandpa waving this copy of the Peeblesshire in the front row shouting, ldquoI won that same prize in ndash prizes really meant something in my day. Perhaps that is a bit fancul but, as your head teacher, I want to thank each and every one of you for succeeding in tough times and bringing such pride and honour to our school. Well done.And well done too to our higher journalism class and their teacher, Ms Ness, for the hard work that brings you this celebration of our fantastic young people. I also extend a special thanks to Jacqueline Wilson, the recently retired headteacher of Kingsland Primary for being our special guest in school awarding the certicates and trophies in preparation for this most unusual of prize giving events..removeCampbell Wilson, PHS rectorSpecial guestSquadron leader Stewart CampbellldquoAs a former Peebles High School pupil, Irsquom delighted to have been asked to support the schoolrsquos annual prize giving. Itrsquos important that not only the winners of these awards are praised but all Peebles High School pupils who have had to deal with their own challenges throughout the year.ldquoI have incredibly fond memories of my time at the school, particularly with the PE department who went above and beyond to help me start on my career path. I urge all of the pupils to enjoy their time at the school, reach out for help and support when it is needed, and never stop chasing their dreams.ldquoCongratulations to all the award winners, your hard work and dedication has been rightly recognised. I wish you all the very best for your next challenges and hope they give you joy along the way.A former pupil of Peebles High School, Stewart joined the RAF as a pilot after completing a bachelor of education in physical education at the University of Edinburgh. A fast jet pilot, Stewart has amassed more than , flight hours and was a Red Arrows pilot during the ,  and  display seasons. Now serving on  Squadron flying the F-B lsquoLightningrsquo Strike Fighter, he is currently deployed on HMS Queen Elizabeth, the Royal Navyrsquos Flagship aircraft carrier.Edited byErin LittleAchievement award winnersThomas Neville: The Maigret Cup for best overall linguistThe Maigret Cup is a prestigious award earned by the best overall linguist student of Peebles High School for the year. The winner of the Maigret Cup this year is Thomas Neville. Thomas has won this award through his success studying Spanish and French at Higher level. The class was fortunate enough to interview Thomas regarding the award and asked him how he felt to have won this. He said: ldquoIrsquom really impressed with myself, obviously the award for overall linguist is really prestigious, and Irsquom really chuffed with myself as there is obviously a lot of languages at this school so to have won the best overall award for languages is something that Irsquom really proud of.ByHarry NessAmy Brown: Outstanding Musical ContributionOn November  the class interviewed former Peebles High School student Amy Brown to discuss her achievement of the Outstanding Musical Contribution Award. This is presented in recognition of the huge commitment made to the extra curricular le of the school and is awarded to a pupil who have been a source of inspiration to their fellow musicians throughout their time at Peebles. She was delighted to have won, even though she only took music for enjoyment and went on to express her disappointment at not being able to perform fully last year. She graciously stated that she was glad pupils are ldquoable to get back to that now and other people are enjoying it. While Amy is not pursuing music further , she explained that ldquoitrsquos not something I want to stop doinghellip It was probably one of my favourite subjects, probably the one I was most relaxed aboutthat makes sense. It was always a nice environment to be in and I think that helped me enjoy it a lot more. Amy then admitted at the risk of sounding ldquoclicheacute, that the music department concerts were the highlight of her years at the school. At the end of the interview, she imparted some very wise advice for younger years. She said: ldquoHave more confidence in yourself, donrsquot care as much about what other people think.ByMadeleine HubertChristopher OrsquoHare: George OB Thomson Memorial CupThis award was created by professor George Thompson, who taught in the English department at Peebles High School. He devoted large parts of his research to the study of pupils with additional needs and was always adamant that they should be integrated into the ldquole and work of the whole school. The council of Tweeddale wanted to celebrate the late professor George Thompson by awarding this memorial quaich to the most creative and enterprising entry from pupils with additional needs for a project devised by the school in conjunction with the society. When the class interviewed Christopher he said he felt ldquobrilliant and honoured to receive this award. He told us that one teacher that improved Christopherrsquos school le was Mr Travis, from the technology department. Christopher described him as a ldquofunny guy and ldquonice person, who he says is happy to help whenever. He added that design and manufacture was his favourite subject as it enabled him to unleash his creativity. Not only is Christopher creative, but funny too, and when asked what his act in a school talent show would be he replied: ldquoI like to make people laugh and feel happy. Finally, Christopher was asked what he wishes to do in the future. Filled with energy, he stated that he would like to join the army. The skills and qualities which Christopher has shown in order to gain this award will help him achieve his future plans. The school wishes Christopher all the best, and know he will do well in the world which anxiously awaits his talent, kindness and phenomenal humour.ByKeeley RippinBen Rorison: George OB Thomson Memorial Cup, and Balfour Medal This yearrsquos worthy prize winner of the Balfour Medal and the George OB Thomson cup is Ben Rorison. Both prizes are awarded to an inidual with a positive presence and creative outlook within their community and school le. This was an area in which Ben excelled. When asked how he felt about receiving both awards Ben stated that he was ldquoshocked and delighted to have been picked. Ben also mentioned that his favourite subject was music and that he wanted to pursue this by becoming a music teacher for those with additional needs. When asked what his favourite memory was at Peebles High, Ben said is was helping first year pupils and helping around the school as a prefect, just showing how deserving of this prize Ben is. The positive impact that Ben had on the school will stay with those students he helped and the teachers he worked with. The school has no doubt that Ben will continue to be a role model and inspiration to all who are fortunate enough to work with him.ByOlivia ThornburrowAbbie Sorrell: Geoffrey Simpson Award for Head PrefectOne winner of the Geoffrey Simpson award is ex-head girl Abbie Sorrell. The classrsquo first question regarded the important issue of who her favourite teacher was. She replied: ldquoI donrsquot really do favourites, butI had to choose it would be Lesley Johnson. Chemistry used to be one of my weaker subjects , however I learned to love it and always looked forward to her classes. However, she may have been won over in another way as she finishes her reply with ldquocake days were always a firm favourite of mine too.Abbie was asked what her favourite memory of Peebles High School was and she responded enthusiastically ldquothe German exchange trip. She added: ldquoI went as a member of the choir and loved meeting like-minded people and embracing a dferent culture. Not to mention the infamous Loch Lomond song which was always a favourite of mine.When asked about her future plans, Abbie replied: ldquoWow, thinking about the future seems so daunting, however I hope that my uni degree will allow me to work in a hospital environment where I can help people. I also love the idea of travel and going on adventures to make some memories.The class asked Abbie to reflect on and offer advice to her first year self, and she responded with ldquothe list is longhellip the main thing Irsquod say is not to be so hard on myself and to accept that set backs are important for learning just as much as success. Carrying on the theme of advice Abbie was asked what she would say to this yearrsquos head team and she told them to ldquoembrace everything because the year will be over before you know it. Therefore, just make the most of every opportunity and most of all enjoy yourself and have fun working with your peers.ByRosie DykesEuan Macrae: Geoffrey Simpson Award for Head PrefectEuan Macrae was awarded the prestigious Geoffrey Simpson Award for his efforts as head boy. Euan had to show certain skills such as leadership and teamwork in order to effectively guide the school. In an interview with Euan, who is now studying Medicine at University, he highlighted how the school fire and COVID had affected his work ethic during his final few years in school, and how this has impacted the lives of not only himself but also his year group going into exams and beyond. He explained that ldquowersquod never sat proper higher exams which would have set us up for the bigger exams that we were going to have to sit further down the line so the damage from that is probably still lasting. The class asked Euan who his hero was, he very honestly answered with his grandfather, saying that he had always looked up to him due to his intelligence and bravery. When asked who his favourite teacher was at school, Euan passionately discussed how Miss Dunlop, who taught history, influenced his high school experience as ldquoshe had the entire class focused on what she was saying and she never even had to raise her voice. I soon realised that learning could be actually so much fun as well as informative.ByLouise RussellRachel McManus: Tweed Reads PrizeCampbell Hunter was a much-loved member of the Peebles community. He made fantastic contributions to the Tweed Reads organisation and thrived under the leadership role. He was kind, compassionate and showed a real love of encouraging the younger generations to explore and enjoy reading. Campbell worked tirelessly alongside the other members of Tweed Reads and valued the importance of learning, community and service. Campbell was such an important part of the community, and his astounding contribution to Tweed Reads only proved how far he was set to go outside of school.The Tweed Reads prize is named after Campbell Hunter, not just to honour his memory but to honour everything he stood for and his contributions to the Tweed Reads club. The prize is awarded to the few who epitomise Campbellrsquos wonderful leadership qualities and share his values of learning and community. The Campbell Hunter prize for  goes to Rachel McManus who consistently worked creatively within the confines of COVID regulations and was always relentlessly positive.When the class asked Rachel about the prize itself and how she felt to have won it, she described Campbell as ldquoa huge part of Tweed Reads in his last few years of high school and had a real passion for helping young children in the community develop their reading skills and form a love for reading. Rachel says she feels ldquohonoured to have won the Campbell Hunter prize through Tweed Reads and she hopes to continue her involvement with the organisation in coming years.When asked in an interview how the fire and pandemic affected her work ethic within school she replied it had ldquoa massive impact on students. She then went on to congratulate the school saying it has ldquoworked hard to ensure that pupils were still able to have a good amount of teaching with being online and there was always support available should anyone have needed it. Rachel closed her answer by admitting that ldquoit was hard to concentrate on work at home, so you really had to push yourself to stay motivated and keep on top of the workload.Rachel was asked how she felt the award carried on Campbellrsquos legacy. She responded saying that it demonstrates all of the commitment he put into Tweed Reads and his caring nature over his home community.She added: ldquoIn my sixth year of high school I heard many stories of Campbell from Tweed Reads leaders who had worked alongside him. They always said how much commitment he had to the charity and how much he cared about truly representing the ethos of the charity so therefore I feel that the Campbell Hunter prize is a true legacy of all the hard work and dedication that he put into the charity.ByRosie Dykes

title: new-caledonia-votes-stay-france-referendum-marred-boycott
story: Voters in the French island territory of New Caledonia have voted overwhelmingly to stay part of France, in a referendum boycotted by pro-independence forces and closely watched around the South Pacic.French President Emmanuel Macron hailed the result as a resounding confirmation of Francersquos role in the Indo-Pacic, and announced negotiations on the territoryrsquos future status. Separatist activists expressed disappointment or resignation.They had urged a delay in the vote because of the pandemic, and were angry over what they said were French government efforts to sway the campaign. So they called on their supporters to stay away from voting stations.And they did. Official results showed % of those who took part chose to stay in France. Overall turnout was just % mdash less than half the numbers who showed up in a previous independence referendum last year, where support for breaking away was .%.vw,vw,px, px"People queue outside a school in Noumea to vote in the referendum ldquoTonight we are French, and we will stay that way. Itrsquos no longer negotiable, said Sonia Backes, president of the Southern Province region and a fervent loyalist.The vote was monitored by the UN and regional powers, amid global efforts towards decolonisation and growing Chinese influence in the region. New Caledonia, colonised by Napoleonrsquos nephew in the th century, is a vast archipelago of about , people east of Australia that is  time zones ahead of Paris mdash and hosts a French military base.ldquoTonight France is more beautul because New Caledonia decided to stay, President Macron said in a national televised address.He did not address the boycott. Noting that the electorate ldquoremains deeply ided, he pledged ldquorespect for all Caledonians, including those who voted to break away.vw,vw,px, px"A woman signs before voting at a polling station in Noumea Sundayrsquos vote was the third and last in a decades-long decolonisation process, which stemmed from violence in  that led to the French government handing New Caledonia broad autonomy under the Noumea Agreement. The process was aimed at settling tensions between native Kanaks seeking independence and those who wanted the territory to remain part of France..removeThe process does not end with the referendum. The state, separatists and non-separatists now have  months to negotiate a new status for the territory and its institutions within France.ldquoWe are reaching a new stage, Mr Macron said, calling for negotiations on new structures to handle health crises, boost the economy, improve womenrsquos rights and protect the environment from climate change mdash a major concern in this island territory.A tropical storm warning also dampened enthusiasm for the vote. Lines snaked out of some polling stations, as winds whipped palm trees lining the streets of the regional capital, Noumea. But turnout at others was barely a trickle.The question put to people in the archipelagorsquos  voting stations was: ldquoDo you want New Caledonia to gain full sovereignty and become independent  Masks and social distancing measures were required.The campaign and voting day were unusually calm because of the boycott.vw,vw,px, px"Voters in Noumea began queuing at .am In the first such referendum in , .% of voters supported independence, and .% favoured it in a second vote held in . While support for a ldquoyes vote seemed to be growing, the regionrsquos first coronavirus outbreak in September threw the political debate into disarray. Until then, New Caledonia had been one of the few virus-free places left in the world.By November, the archipelago had reported  Covid- deaths, and the regional senate decreed a year of traditional Kanak mourning. Independence activists felt they could not campaign out of respect for their dead, and demanded that the referendum be postponed.But pro-France groups insisted the vote should take place as scheduled to end uncertainty over New Caledoniarsquos future and to boost its economic prospects. Pro-independence activists announced they would refuse to take part, accusing the government in Paris of imposing the referendum date and violating neutrality by publishing a document seen as casting the consequences of independence in a negative light.vw,vw,px, px"French police and gendarmerie units have been deployed across Noumea France is trying to cement its presence in the Indo-Pacic region after it lost a multibillion-dollar submarine contract because of a partnership Australia formed with the US and the UK. The secretly negotiated submarine project, announced in September and aimed at countering Chinese ambitions in the region, was a huge blow to France. New Caledonia hosts one of two French military bases in the Pacic.Mr Macron said the vote sent an important message to the Indo-Pacic region while it undergoes ldquorecomposition and faces ldquostrong tensions.The UN has supported New Caledoniarsquos decolonisation process and sent electoral observers to monitor Sundayrsquos vote. The Pacic Islands Forum also sent a delegation to observe the poll..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: New Caledonia votes to stay in France in referendum marred by boycott

title: uk-covid-alert-level-raised-following-rapid-increase-omicron-cases
story: The UK Covid alert level has been raised following a rapid increase in Omicron cases being recorded.The countryrsquos four chief medical officers and NHS Englandrsquos national medical director have recommended to ministers that the UK go up to Level  from Level .It comes as Boris Johnson prepares to address the nation at pm about the booster vaccine programme.The message ndash which PA news agency understands will not see new restrictions announced ndash will be pre-recorded, meaning the Prime Minister will be able to avoid answering questions about suggestions he broke coronavirus rules by attending a virtual Downing Street staff Christmas quiz last December.The decision to increase the alert level follows advice from the UK Health Security Agencyafter a further , confirmed cases of the Omicron mutation were recorded in the UK as of Sunday.It brings the total number of UK cases of Omicron to ,, a % increase from Saturdayrsquos total of , UK cases.Increasing the UK Covid alert level to Level  means the epidemic is ldquoin general circulation, transmission is high and direct Covid- pressure on healthcare services is widespread and substantial or rising, according to Government guidance.vw,vw,px, px"Prime Minister Boris Johnson is due to give an update on the booster programme on Sunday In a joint statement, the CMOs and NHS Englandrsquos Professor Stephen Powis said the emergence of Omicron ldquoadds additional and rapidly increasing risk to the public and healthcare services.They added: ldquoEarly evidence shows that Omicron is spreading much faster than Delta and that vaccine protection against symptomatic disease from Omicron is reduced.ldquoData on severity will become clearer over the coming weeks but hospitalisations from Omicron are already occurring and these are likely to increase rapidly.The five officials, including Englandrsquos CMO Professor Chris Whitty, Northern Irelandrsquos Sir Michael McBride, Scotlandrsquos Professor Gregor Smith, and Walesrsquo Dr Frank Atherton, said the NHS was already under pressure ldquomainly driven by non-Covid pressures, with Omicronrsquos ability to escape vaccines ldquolikely to add to those demands..removeldquoIt is extremely important thatyou are eligible, you get your Covid vaccination now ndash whether this be your first, second or booster dose, they said.ldquoPeople should continue to take sensible precautions including ventilating rooms, using face coverings, testing regularly and isolating when symptomatic.vw,vw,px, px"Chief medical officer for England Prof Chris Whitty was one of those to recommend the alert level be raised The development comes as it was warned more restrictions may be needed to tackle Omicron, with the UK facing an ldquoinevitable large wave of infections.That is according to Dr Susan Hopkins, the chief medical adviser for the UKHSA, who said people will have to reduce social contact as much as possible, with Omicron cases being detected among hospital patients ndash although no deaths have yet been reported as a result of contracting it.Dr Hopkins said more measures may be needed, adding that the Government has ldquovery dficult decisions ahead, even after triggering its winter Plan B proposals, which include introducing Covid passports for large venues.ldquoI think that the restrictions that the Government have announced are sensible. I think that we may need to go beyond them. But wersquoll need to watch carefully what happens with hospitalisations, she told the BBC.#OmicronVariantlatest information additional confirmed cases of the #Omicroniant of #COVIDhave been reported across the UK. The total number of confirmed COVID- Omicron cases in the UK is ,. pic uAWPpmdash UK Health Security AgencyDecember , Education Secretary and former vaccines minister Nadhim Zahawi described the UK as in a ldquorace to get the coronavirus booster to eligible adults ldquoas quickly as possible.New modelling suggests that, under one scenario, almost twice the number of coronavirus patients could be admitted to hospital compared with last year due to the impact of Omicron.Experts from the London School of Hygiene  Tropical Medicinecalculated figures which say a large wave of infections could occur over the next few monthstougher measures are not brought in.Analysis by the UKHSA has found that the AstraZeneca and Pfizer vaccines provide ldquomuch lower levels of protection against symptomatic infection with Omicron compared with Delta.vw,vw,px, px"Dr Susan Hopkins said people must reduce social contact as much as possible But the UKHSA said a booster dose gives around % to % protection against symptomatic infection with Omicron, as it urged people to have their boosters.All eligible adults can book their booster jab two monthsafter their second dose using the NHS national booking system, getting their top-up in protection three monthson from their second dose.The national booking system will open to everyone aged  to  in England from Monday.Meanwhile, double-jabbed people identied as a contact of someone with Covid- in England will be told to take a daily rapid test for seven days from Tuesday.Unvaccinated adults are not eligible for the new daily testing policy and they must self-isolate for  daysthey are a contact of someone who tests positive..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: UK Covid alert level raised following rapid increase in Omicron cases

title: covid-scotland-booster-jabs-appear-vaccine-passports-december-9
story: Scotlands deputy first minister confirmed this morning that the Covid booster jab will appear on Scottish vaccine passports for internationaltravel from December .Speaking on Good Morning Scotland, John Swinney said that proof of the booster jab would appear on vaccine passports for international travel from Thursday December .He added that this would be extended to the domestic vaccine certicationscheme, however this would take slightly longer to implement.When asked whether booster jabs would be included in the vaccine passport scheme, the deputy first minister said: "For international travelit will from  December."And we will expand that for domestic certication but that will take us a little more time to do that. But the critical requirement is for international travel and those changes will be applied from  December."How to get proof of booster jab on vaccine passport According to the Scottish government, the NHSScotlandCovid Status app will update on Thursday December  to show proof of the booster jab.Depending on the settings on your phone, this will either update automatically or will require you to do it manually.If you need to update your app manually, you can do so by going to the app store and clicking on the small person icon in the top right corner.This will take you to your account details, where it will show you a list of the apps you have downloaded on your phone.Next to the app, there should be an option to update.The Scottish government has said that it will take dfering times for the update to roll out everywhere, but that it is currently underway as of lunch time on Thursday.Why is it important that boosters show on vaccine passports To travel to some countries, you must have been fully vaccinated against Covidwithin a certain time limitprior to your visit, which ranges from -days to a year.With Covid jabs rolled out from late last year, it means that some people will already be barred from travelthey cannot provide proof of a booster jab..removeProof of a booster jab will therefore help people to meet the vaccination requirements of certain countries.Who can get a booster jab in Scotland All adults in Scotland will be offered a booster vaccine as advised by the JCVI after results showed a third vaccine signicantly improved protection against serious infection.The booster jabs aim to curb a potentialwave of infections caused by the Omicron iant.So far, everyone aged  and over and people who are clinically vulnerable have been invited to book their booster jabs in Scotland.But soon, everyone over the age of  will beable to book a booster jab.These third doses will be offered no less than three months after the second dose of the vaccine was administered.This time frame between second vaccine and booster jab has been cut from six months to three, as advised by the JCVI.

title: covid-scotland-get-proof-booster-jab-vaccine-passport-app
story: Proof of booster jabs on the Scottish NHS Covid Status app will become available fromThursday December , according to the Scottish government.To travelto some countries, you must have been fully vaccinated against Covidwithin a certain time limitprior to your visit, which ranges from -days to a year.With Covid jabs rolled out from late last year, it means that some people will already be barred from travelthey cannot provide proof of a booster jab.Proof of a third vaccinewill therefore help people to meet the vaccination requirements of certain countries.While proof of booster jabs was introduced in England in November, the update of the Scottish NHS vaccine passport app is taking place today.Heres how to get proof of the booster jab for internationaltravel.How to get proof of the booster jab for international travel According to the Scottish government, the NHS ScotlandCovid Status app will update today to show proof of the booster jab.Depending on the settings on your phone, this will either update automatically or will require you to do it manually.If you need to update your app manually, you can do so by going to the app store and clicking on the small person icon in the top right corner.This will take you to your account details, where it will show you a list of the apps you have downloaded on your phone.Next to the app, there should be an option to update.The Scottish government has said that it will take dfering times for the update to roll out everywhere, but that it is currently underway as of lunch time on Thursday.How to download theNHS Scotland Covid Status AppYou can download your vaccine passporton your smartphonevia theNHS Scotland Covid Status App.Simply head to the app store on your device and search NHS Scotland Covid Status App, which is free to download.You must firstly read andagree to the privacy policy which explains how the app works..removeThen you can either sign-inyou have previously made an account or sign upyou are yet to create one.If you are signing up, it will ask you to very your identity by uploading a photo of your passport or driving license and scanning your face with your camera.Once you have veried your identity, you can sign up by entering your email address and sending a verication code to this address.It will then ask you to enter the verication code before creating a password and confirming your account.You will be asked for your CHI number, however it is not a problemyou dont know it - you can skip this step by clicking "No" whenaskedyou know your number.The app will then display your name and date of birth as shown on your ID, and ask for the gender towhich you identy.You must then create a memorable  number pin.This is the final step in creating your account.The app should then show your vaccine status, including details of initial twojabs and the booster vaccine, barcodes for each and theof time since each of these vaccinations.Each time you sign into the app you will be asked to enter the memorable code.

title: covid-scotland-current-restrictions
story: Boris Johnson announced further Covid restrictions in England on Wednesday, but what are the rules in Scotland The Scottish government is responsible for its own response to the pandemic, and therefore implements its own restrictions and measures surrounding Covid.While the prime minister yesterday implemented new measures in England, many of these were already in place in Scotland.Here is everything you need to know about the current Covid restrictions in Scotland...What are the current Covid measures in Scotland These are the current Covid regulations in place in Scotland:masks and face coverings on publictransport, in shops and when moving around in hospitality settingsCovid vaccine passport scheme - proof of vaccination or a negative lateral flow test required in nightclubs,indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with + peopleunseated and any event with ,+ peoplework from home has been urged wherever possible, with the government saying anyone who worked from home at the beginning of the pandemic should do so againWhat are the isolation rules in Scotland There are dferent rules depending on whether it is the newOmicron iant or the Delta iant.Anyone who tests positive forOmicron iant in Scotland must self isolate for  days.All close contacts of suspected Omicron infections must self isolate for -days, whether they are fully vaccinated or not.People will be told when they receive their PCR resultsthey have the Omicron iant.Anyone who tests positive for any iant of Covid- must self-isolate for -days.However,this is not the Omicron iant there are dferent rules for close contacts who are fully vaccinated.If you are fully vaccinated and a close contact of someone who tests positive for non-Omicron Covid, you must isolate until you get a PCR test.Ifyourresult then comes back negative and youremain asymptomatic, you will no longer have to isolate..removeHoweveryou are not vaccinated or only partially vaccinated and are identied as a close contact of someone with Covid,you must isolate for -days regardless of the result of your PCR test.What are thetravelrules for Scotland The travelrules are the same across the UK.Everyone travelling from overseas must take a pre-departure and post-arrival test regardless of vaccination status.You must take a test within -hours before your flightto the UK, and test within -hours of your arrival in the UK, isolating until you receive these results.If you are fully vaccinated and receive a negative result, you can leave isolation.If you are not fully vaccinated you must isolate for -days and take a further day- test.If you are travelling from a country on the red list, you must isolate in a quarantine hotel.Will more restrictions be introduced in Scotland Tweeting on Wednesday night, first minister Nicola Sturgeon said: "Re UK gov announcement of Covid Plan B today, all these protections are already in place in and have helped us get Delta cases down."Tough question we all face in period ahead is whether these protections will be strong enough against a rapidly spreading Omicron ianthellip"Even Omicron doesnrsquot cause more severe disease, the numbers of people who might be infected by its faster spread will create big challenges for NHS and economy- so we need to consider carefullywhat proportionate response needed."In meantime, all of us complying strictly with current protections will help. And evenyou feel angry with a politician just now, please remember just how important compliance is for the healthsafety of you, your loved ones and the country"

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: rising-star-joins-east-festival-2022-line-up
story: He will join headliners The Kooks and Ministry of Sound Classical, plus Shed Seven, Circa Waves, Sister Sledge and The Futureheads.The two-day, family-friendly festival will feature a erse blend of live music, street food, art, culture and wellbeing events on August  and  next year.Callum played a special set ahead of Scotlandrsquos first Autumn Nations Series rugby match against Tonga at Murrayfield in October has had a sold-out Scottish tour and will be supporting fellow Scottish musician Amy Macdonald on her UK tour, including a show at the OVO Hydro in Glasgow this month.Callumrsquos debut album, People Like Us, reached No.  in The Official Scottish Album Chart and No.  in The Official UK Album Sales Charts last year.Shane Grieve, Out East Festival director, said: ldquoWersquore back, bigger and better for . The summer will be all about celebrating the good things in le and wersquore delighted that Out East will be at the centre of that.Stephen Begg, operations manager at Dalkeith Country Park, added: ldquoWe are ecstatic to be hosting Out East Festival  at Dalkeith Country Park. We canrsquot wait. The parkrsquos expanse of beautul greenery is the perfect backdrop for this vibrant music, art and culture-focussed, family-friendly event.In addition to the musical line-up, Out East will offer a well-being area, lsquoThe Breakoutrsquo, nestled amongst the trees with wildle.At lsquoThe Outpostrsquo, an open-air cabaret stage, an eclectic mix of art and culture, including comedy and dance theatre, will take place. Everything from storytelling, science and circus activities is available at lsquoSchoolrsquos Outrsquo, while lsquoThe Pig Outrsquo will be curated by Canteen, offering ious culinary delights. A fairground can also be enjoyed at lsquoFar Outrsquo.For more information, go to outeastfest

title: josh-taylor-putting-aside-friendship-lee-catterall-ahead-title-defence
story: The Prestonpans man has no issues with the mandatory challenger from Chorley, who was in Las Vegas in May backing Taylor when he unied all four light-welterweight belts with a convincing decision win over the previously undefeated Jose Ramirez, which also extended his unbeaten record to -.Speaking at The Royal Scots Club in Edinburgh, where both boxers were publicising their fight at The SSE Hydro Arena, -year-old Taylor revealed a changed attitude towards Catterall, also unbeaten with a - record and a former British and WBO Intercontinental champion.The WBC, WBA, IBF and WBO champion said: ldquoI like Jack. I have a lot of time for him. There is no bad blood there, there never has been.ldquoBut the mindset towards him now changes and that is easy for me.ldquoI can change the mindset with a click of my fingers. I am a fighting man and it is easy to change that mindset.ldquoI am getting sick of looking at his face already. I just want to get in the ring and beat him up and keep my beltsldquoAt the end of the day, he is coming for what I worked so hard to achieve. I came up the hard way, I had to beat champion after champion, undefeated fighter after undefeated fighter, so he is getting the chance of all this glory in one fight.ldquoIt is my job to make sure he gets nowhere near it. I donrsquot think he will bring anything I havenrsquot seen before and he hasnrsquot fought anywhere near the level that I have. This will be a telling factor on fight night.Fans can sign up for pre-sale tickets at boxxer

title: musselburgh-racecourse-fans-staff-don-christmas-jumpers-charity
story: The Seven National Hunt races over jumps got racing fans in the festive spirit and trackside they were encouraged to wear festive jumpers to raise money for the Injured Jockeys Fund.Racecourse staff played their part by sporting their own festive knitwear at the Scottish Racing Academy Christmas Jumper Race Day.SRA members took a collection for the Injured Jockeys Fund, founded in  to support jockeys who are injured, unable to ride or in need of assistance.The SRArsquos equicizer ndash a racing simulator ndash was onsite and racegoers were able to test their potential to be a jockey, with scores kept throughout the day.Aisling Johnston, Musselburgh Racecourse marketing manager, said: ldquoEveryone loves to pull on a Christmas jumper and we were delighted that racegoers got right into the Christmas spirit and helped us raise funds for the very deserving Injured Jockeyrsquos Fund.Hannah Farrell, of The Scottish Racing Academy, said: ldquoWe were very happy to support Musselburgh Racecoursersquos Christmas Jumper festivities, and it was an added bonus that the Injured Jockeyrsquos charity benefited from this generous initiative.Musselburgh Racecourse is back in action on December .For more information and to book tickets, visit www.musselburgh-racecourse

title: residents-launch-campaign-tranent-pubs-closure-sold-housing
story: Hawthorn Leisure, which owns The Tower Inn, notied husband-and-we duo John and Tracy Reynolds, who have run the pub for the last nine years, that the building had been sold.The pub, established in , has served the local community for nearly  years but staff at the well-loved watering hole will pour the pubrsquos final pint on January  ndash leaving just three public houses in the town: Whispers, The Brig Inn and The Tranent Arms.John, , expressed his sadness at losing the pub and said: ldquoThere will certainly have been a few stories told over the last century inside this place.ldquoIt has also been the site where a lot of friendships have been made and jobs created over the years.ldquoWe have all shared lots of laughter, tears of joy and sadness, and each of us will have our own little memories but, sadly, Tranent is losing another community hub.ldquoTracy and I would like to thank everyone over the last nine years for their custom and support, and not to mention the numerous amount of friends we have made during our time here.ldquoWe also remember the characters and friends who are no longer with us, some of whom were the most loyal customers we have ever come across.ldquoCovid has not been kind to a lot of businesses, particularly those in the hospitality sector, but as the saying goes, lsquouse it or lose itrsquo, which will apply to the remainder of pubs and clubs that are left in Tranent.The pub was put up for sale earlier in the year, with Mr and Mrs Reynolds only finding out about its sale status a week before it re-opened following the relaxation of Covid- restrictions on May .Now, Tower Inn punters are banding together to save the establishment from closure.A Facebook page ndash titled Save the Tower Inn ndash has gathered more than  followers upon its creation.Victor Nelson, Save the Tower Inn spokesperson, said: ldquoIt is a pub that has maintained its traditions over the years, providing a warm and friendly atmosphere as well as much-needed support and friendships to those in the community that have needed it most.ldquoIn recent years, the Tower has set up a menrsquos social group which raised money to donate to local community projects.ldquoThis provided assistance towards buying memorial benches for use within the community and also gave the Hub at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary the money to buy two communication devices to give non-verbal pupils a voice.ldquoEarlier this year, the brewery that owned the pub put the Tower Inn up for sale and invited offers to all parties with the view to selling the property to the highest bidder.ldquoA number of the interested parties submitted offers that would have continued to run the property as a pub but sadly failed in the highest bid process, meaning the property has now been sold for residential purposes that will see the pub close its doors for the final time mid January  ndash a sad loss that will see people lose their jobs, East Lothian lose another traditional establishment and the community lose another local hub.Kenny McLeod, ward councillor, said: ldquoI am disappointed to see another pub shut in Tranent after well over  years since it opened ndash another gathering place for people of Tranent to meet and catch up.ldquoWe have lost so many establishments such as the Legion, Labour Club and The Plough.ldquoWe now only have Whispers, The Brig Inn and The Tranent Arms left when it comes to pubs, but we still have the Store Club and the rugby club, along with the bowling clubs available.A spokesperson for Hawthorn said: ldquoWe are strong believers in the importance of community pubs.ldquoUnfortunately, despite our best efforts, we have been unable to find a new partner to take over The Tower Inn when our current tenantrsquos lease ends in January, so we have taken the decision to sell the pub.
